Comment: IBP engages external security consultants for annual independent security assessments as documented in the Compliance and Audit Management Policy. Question Text: Do you have a program in place that includes the ability to monitor changes to the regulatory requirements in relevant jurisdictions, adjust your security program for changes to legal requirements, and ensure compliance with relevant regulatory requirements
Comment: The Compliance and Audit Management Policy includes regulatory monitoring for GDPR, AWS security standards, and industry requirements. Question Text: Do you use industry standards (i.e. OWASP Software Assurance Maturity Model, ISO 27034) to build in security for your Systems/Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)
Comment: IBP follows OWASP Software Assurance Maturity Model and ISO 27034 principles as documented in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Question Text: Do you use an automated source code analysis tool to detect security defects in code prior to production
Comment: IBP implements SonarQube for automated static code analysis as part of the CI/CD pipeline, as specified in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. The system performs security-focused code reviews with dependency scanning for vulnerable components and secret scanning to prevent credential commits before production deployment.

Question Text: Do you use manual source-code analysis to detect security defects in code prior to production
Comment: IBP requires peer security-focused code reviews for all changes as documented in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. All code changes undergo manual review using security checklists covering input validation, SQL injection prevention, authentication, and authorization controls before production release.

Question Text: Do you verify that all of your software suppliers adhere to industry standards for Systems/Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) security
Comment: The Vendor and Third Party Management Policy requires security assessments of all software vendors, including review of their SDLC security practices. Critical vendors must provide evidence of secure development practices, security certifications (ISO 27001, SOC 2), and undergo annual security reviews to ensure continued adherence to security standards.

Question Text: (SaaS only) Do you review your applications for security vulnerabilities and address any issues prior to deployment to production
Comment: IBP implements comprehensive security testing including automated OWASP ZAP dynamic scanning, vulnerability scanning in CI/CD pipelines, and manual penetration testing as documented in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Recent security improvements include OTP implementation, password reset token security, and enumeration resistance controls. AWS Inspector provides automated EC2 and container scanning.

Question Text: Are all identified security, contractual, and regulatory requirements for customer access contractually addressed and remediated prior to granting customers access to data, assets, and information systems
Comment: The Access Control and Identity Management Policy requires manager approval for all access requests with documented business justification. Customer access requirements are evaluated through risk assessment and implemented via role-based access controls with MFA enforcement. All access is governed by contractual obligations as managed through the Vendor and Third Party Management Policy.

Question Text: Are all requirements and trust levels for customers' access defined and documented
Comment: IBP maintains a two-tier access model (Standard and Administrative) as documented in the Access Control and Identity Management Policy. Access levels are clearly defined with specific permissions, MFA requirements, and review frequencies. Customer access requirements are documented with appropriate authentication methods and session management controls.

Question Text: Does your data management policies and procedures require audits to verify data input and output integrity routines
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy includes comprehensive data quality management with accuracy monitoring (>99% target), completeness checks (<1% missing values), and consistency verification across systems. Regular audits verify data input validation and output integrity through automated quality assessments and manual verification procedures.

Question Text: Are data input and output integrity routines (i.e. MD5/SHA checksums) implemented for application interfaces and databases to prevent manual or systematic processing errors or corruption of data
Comment: IBP implements comprehensive data validation controls as specified in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Input validation is enforced through Spring Validation, database integrity is maintained through parameterized queries, and AWS services provide built-in checksums for S3 storage and RDS transactions to ensure data integrity across all interfaces.

Question Text: Is your Data Security Architecture designed using an industry standard (e.g., CDSA, MULITSAFE, CSA Trusted Cloud Architectural Standard, FedRAMP, CAESARS)
Comment: IBP's data security architecture follows AWS Well-Architected Framework security principles and aligns with CSA Trusted Cloud Architectural Standards as documented in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. The architecture implements defense-in-depth with VPC isolation, security groups, encryption at rest and in transit, and comprehensive logging and monitoring.

Question Text: Does your organization have a plan or framework for business continuity management or disaster recovery management
Comment: IBP maintains comprehensive business continuity and disaster recovery plans as documented in the Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy. The framework includes multi-AZ AWS deployment, automated failover capabilities, cross-region backup replication, and defined Recovery Time Objectives (RTO: <4 hours) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO: <1 hour).

Question Text: Do you have more than one provider for each service you depend on
Comment: As a cloud-native organization, IBP primarily relies on AWS services for infrastructure. However, we implement redundancy through multi-AZ deployment, multiple AWS regions (eu-west-1 primary, eu-central-1 secondary), and diverse service endpoints. For critical business functions, we maintain relationships with alternative providers (Google Workspace for business applications) as documented in our Vendor Management Policy.

Question Text: Do you provide a disaster recovery capability
Comment: IBP provides comprehensive disaster recovery with automated RDS Multi-AZ failover (<1 hour RTO), cross-region S3 replication (<15 minutes RPO), and Infrastructure-as-Code rapid redeployment capabilities as specified in the Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy. Disaster recovery procedures are tested monthly with annual full DR exercises.

Question Text: Do you monitor service continuity with upstream providers in the event of provider failure
Comment: The Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy includes monitoring of critical vendor services through automated health checks, AWS Service Health Dashboard monitoring, and vendor SLA tracking. We maintain documented escalation procedures and alternative service activation plans for upstream provider failures.

Question Text: Do you provide access to operational redundancy reports, including the services you rely on
Comment: IBP provides customers with operational redundancy documentation as outlined in our Business Continuity Policy, including multi-AZ deployment architecture, backup strategies, and vendor dependency mapping. Monthly operational reports include availability metrics, backup success rates, and redundancy verification testing results.

Question Text: Do you provide a tenant-triggered failover option
Comment: Current architecture uses automated failover rather than tenant-triggered options. Multi-AZ RDS provides automatic database failover, and Route 53 health checks enable automatic DNS failover. For a small team operation, automated failover provides more reliable service restoration than manual triggers. We can implement tenant-triggered failover capabilities if required by specific customer agreements.

Question Text: Do you share your business continuity and redundancy plans with your tenants
Comment: The Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy provides for sharing business continuity documentation with customers under appropriate confidentiality agreements. We provide architecture diagrams, RTO/RPO targets, redundancy descriptions, and communication procedures while protecting sensitive operational details.

Question Text: Are business continuity plans subject to testing at planned intervals or upon significant organizational or environmental changes to ensure continuing effectiveness
Comment: IBP conducts monthly backup restoration testing, quarterly tabletop exercises, and annual full disaster recovery tests as documented in the Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy. Plans are updated following any significant infrastructure changes, and test results are documented with improvement actions tracked to completion.

Question Text: Does your organization adhere to any international or industry standards when it comes to securing, monitoring, maintaining and testing of datacenter utilities services and environmental conditions
Comment: IBP leverages AWS data center facilities that maintain SOC 1/2/3 compliance, ISO 27001 certification, and comprehensive physical security as verified through AWS compliance documentation. Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy references AWS physical security validation and environmental controls including redundant power, cooling, and fire suppression systems.

Question Text: Has your organization implemented environmental controls, fail-over mechanisms or other redundancies to secure utility services and mitigate environmental conditions
Comment: Through AWS infrastructure, IBP benefits from enterprise-grade environmental controls including redundant power systems, UPS backup, emergency generators, and multi-AZ deployment for utility service redundancy. AWS data centers provide 24/7 environmental monitoring with automated failover as documented in our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy.

Question Text: Are information system documents (e.g., administrator and user guides, architecture diagrams, etc.) made available to authorized personnel to ensure configuration, installation and operation of the information system
Comment: The Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy requires comprehensive documentation including system architecture diagrams, configuration standards, and operational procedures. Question Text: Are any of your data centers located in places that have a high probability/occurrence of high-impact environmental risks (floods, tornadoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, etc.)

AWS implements comprehensive disaster resilience including seismic design, flood protection, and weather monitoring. Multi-AZ deployment and cross-region replication provide protection against localized environmental risks as documented in our Business Continuity Policy.

Question Text: Do you have documented policies, procedures and supporting business processes for equipment and datacenter maintenance
Comment: Through AWS managed services, IBP benefits from comprehensive data center maintenance procedures including scheduled maintenance windows, redundant systems, and automated failover during maintenance as documented in our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Question Text: Do you have an equipment and datacenter maintenance routine or plan
Comment: IBP leverages AWS managed maintenance including automated patching via Systems Manager, scheduled maintenance windows for RDS, and proactive hardware replacement as specified in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Our change management processes ensure maintenance activities are scheduled, communicated, and verified for successful completion.

Question Text: Are security mechanisms and redundancies implemented to protect equipment from utility service outages (e.g., power failures, network disruptions, etc.)

Question Text: Do you use industry standards and frameworks to determine the impact of any disruption to your organization (i.e. criticality of services and recovery priorities, disruption tolerance, RPO and RTO etc)

Question Text: Have you implemented backup or recovery mechanisms to ensure compliance with regulatory, statutory, contractual or business requirements

Question Text: Do you have controls in place to ensure that standards of quality are being met for all software development

Comment: IBP's change management process includes comprehensive risk assessment, testing requirements, rollback procedures, and monitoring protocols as documented in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Comment: All production changes are tracked through automated deployment systems with approval workflows, SLA impact assessment, and monitoring verification as specified in the Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Comment: IBP maintains asset classification based on business criticality as documented in the Incident Response and Business Continuity Policy. Question Text: Do you maintain a complete inventory of all of your critical assets located at all sites/ or geographical locations and their assigned ownership
Comment: The Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy requires comprehensive asset inventory management including AWS resources, applications, and data assets with assigned ownership, geographic location (EU regions), and criticality classification. Question Text: Are physical security perimeters (e.g., fences, walls, barriers, guards, gates, electronic surveillance, physical authentication mechanisms, reception desks, and security patrols) implemented for all areas housing sensitive data and information systems
Comment: IBP leverages AWS data center physical security including multi-layered perimeter security, biometric access controls, 24/7 guards, CCTV surveillance, and electronic access controls as verified through AWS SOC compliance reports. Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy references AWS physical security validation and monitoring.

Comment: AWS provides geographic location authentication through IP address validation, VPC geographic restrictions, and location-based IAM policies. Question Text: Is automated equipment identification used as a method to validate connection authentication integrity based on known equipment location
Comment: AWS provides automated instance identification through instance metadata, hardware attestation, and certificate-based authentication. Comment: The Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy requires management authorization for any data or system relocation. Question Text: Can you provide tenants with your asset management policies and procedures
Comment: IBP provides asset management documentation including inventory procedures, classification standards, and ownership assignments as documented in our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy. Asset management policies are available to customers under appropriate confidentiality agreements with regular updates communicated as needed.

Question Text: Can you provide evidence that policies, standards, and procedures have been established for maintaining a safe and secure working environment in offices, rooms, facilities, and secure areas
Comment: The Remote Work Security Policy establishes comprehensive workspace security requirements for our remote team including private work areas, secure equipment storage, physical security controls, and environmental protections. Documentation includes home office security standards and training materials for all team members.

Question Text: Can you provide evidence that your personnel and involved third parties have been trained regarding your documented policies, standards, and procedures
Comment: IBP maintains comprehensive security training records as documented in the Remote Work Security Policy and Compliance and Audit Management Policy. Training includes annual security awareness, role-specific security training, and competency assessments with documented completion rates and effectiveness measurement.

Question Text: Are physical access control mechanisms (e.g. CCTV cameras, ID cards, checkpoints) in place to secure, constrain and monitor egress and ingress points
Comment: Through AWS data centers, IBP benefits from enterprise-grade physical access controls including biometric authentication, RFID badges, multi-factor access controls, CCTV surveillance, and visitor escort procedures as documented in AWS SOC compliance reports and verified through our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy.

Question Text: Are ingress and egress points, such as service areas and other points where unauthorized personnel may enter the premises, monitored, controlled and isolated from data storage and process
Comment: AWS data centers provide comprehensive perimeter security with controlled ingress/egress points, service area isolation, visitor management, and separation of service areas from data processing facilities. Our Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy references AWS physical security validation and isolation procedures.

Question Text: Do you restrict physical access to information assets and functions by users and support personnel
Comment: Physical access is controlled through AWS data center security with role-based access, biometric authentication, and escort requirements for sensitive areas. Question Text: Do you provide a capability to identify data and virtual machines via policy tags/metadata (e.g., tags can be used to limit guest operating systems from booting/instantiating/transporting data in the wrong country)
Comment: IBP implements comprehensive AWS resource tagging including data classification labels, geographic restrictions, and policy enforcement as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. Question Text: Do you provide a capability to identify data and hardware via policy tags/metadata/hardware tags (e.g., TXT/TPM, VN-Tag, etc.)
Comment: AWS provides hardware-level security through TPM, hardware security modules, and instance metadata services. Question Text: Do you inventory, document, and maintain data flows for data that is resident (permanent or temporary) within the services' applications and infrastructure network and systems
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy requires comprehensive data flow documentation including data mapping, processing activities records, and system data flows. Data inventory covers breeding data, personal data, operational data, and system data with documented sources, processing purposes, and retention requirements.

Question Text: Can you ensure that data does not migrate beyond a defined geographical residency
Comment: IBP ensures data residency through AWS region controls configured to restrict data to EU regions (eu-west-1 and eu-central-1) as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. Geographic restrictions are enforced through IAM policies, S3 bucket policies, and VPC configuration preventing data migration outside defined boundaries.

Question Text: Do you provide standardized (e.g. ISO/IEC) non-proprietary encryption algorithms (3DES, AES, etc.) to tenants in order for them to protect their data if it is required to move through public networks (e.g., the Internet)
Comment: IBP implements industry-standard AES-256 encryption for data at rest and TLS 1.3 for data in transit as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. All encryption uses standardized, non-proprietary algorithms (AES, RSA, ECDHE) with customer-managed KMS keys available for enhanced control of encryption keys.

Question Text: Do you utilize open encryption methodologies any time your infrastructure components need to communicate with each other via public networks (e.g., Internet-based replication of data from one environment to another)
Comment: All inter-service communications use standard TLS 1.3 encryption with certificate validation, cross-region replication uses AES-256 encryption, and VPN connections utilize industry-standard IPSec protocols as specified in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. No proprietary encryption methods are used for any communications.

Question Text: Are policies and procedures established for data labeling and handling in order to ensure the security of data and objects that contain data
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy establishes a three-tier classification system (Public, Internal, Restricted) with specific handling requirements for each level. Data labeling includes metadata tags, access controls, and retention policies with automated enforcement through AWS resource tagging and IAM policies.

Question Text: Do you follow a structured data-labeling standard (e.g., ISO 15489, Oasis XML Catalog Specification, CSA data type guidance)
Comment: IBP follows structured data labeling aligned with CSA data type guidance and ISO principles as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. Labeling includes classification level, data owner, retention period, privacy category, and handling instructions with consistent metadata standards across all data assets.

Question Text: Are mechanisms for label inheritance implemented for objects that act as aggregate containers for data
Comment: AWS services provide automatic metadata inheritance for containers, with S3 bucket policies inheriting to objects, IAM role permissions applying to associated resources, and data classification tags propagating through container hierarchies as managed through our Data Protection and Privacy Policy procedures.

Question Text: Do you have procedures in place to ensure production data shall not be replicated or used in non-production environments
Comment: The Technology and Infrastructure Security Policy requires strict separation between production and non-production environments. Production data is prohibited in development/testing environments, with data masking, synthetic data generation, and separate AWS accounts ensuring production data isolation with documented controls and monitoring.

Question Text: Are the responsibilities regarding data stewardship defined, assigned, documented, and communicated
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy defines data stewardship roles including Data Owner (business accountability), Data Steward (day-to-day management), Data Custodian (technical management), and Data User (consumption) responsibilities. Role assignments are documented and communicated through policy training and role-specific procedures.

Question Text: Do you support the secure deletion (e.g., degaussing/cryptographic wiping) of archived and backed-up data
Comment: IBP implements secure deletion through cryptographic erasure via KMS key destruction and secure wiping procedures as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. NIST SP 800-88 guidelines are followed for media sanitization with documented deletion certificates and verification procedures for compliance requirements.

Question Text: Can you provide a published procedure for exiting the service arrangement, including assurance to sanitize all computing resources of tenant data once a customer has exited your environment or has vacated a resource
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy includes comprehensive data disposal procedures with cryptographic erasure, deletion verification, and certificates of destruction. Customer exit procedures ensure complete data removal within defined timeframes with documented verification and compliance reporting as specified in service agreements.

Question Text: Do you have key management policies binding keys to identifiable owners
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy establishes key management procedures with documented ownership for each encryption key lifecycle stage. AWS KMS provides key ownership tracking with customer-managed keys assigned to specific services and data classifications with comprehensive access logging and audit trails.

Question Text: Do you have a capability to allow creation of unique encryption keys per tenant
Comment: IBP can implement customer-specific encryption keys through AWS KMS customer-managed keys, allowing unique key generation, ownership, and management per tenant as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. Key separation ensures tenant data encryption independence with dedicated key management capabilities.

Question Text: Do you have a capability to manage encryption keys on behalf of tenants
Comment: AWS KMS provides comprehensive key management services including automatic rotation, access control, and lifecycle management as specified in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. IBP can manage customer keys through secure procedures with appropriate access controls and audit trails for tenant key management requirements.

Question Text: Do you maintain key management procedures
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy establishes comprehensive key management procedures including generation, distribution, usage, rotation, archival, and destruction with documented roles and responsibilities. Procedures cover AWS managed keys, customer-managed keys, and application-level key management with regular reviews and updates.

Question Text: Do you have documented ownership for each stage of the lifecycle of encryption keys
Comment: Key lifecycle ownership is documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy with specific responsibilities for generation (AWS/Customer), distribution (automated), usage (application services), rotation (automated/manual), and destruction (secure deletion). Each stage includes designated owners and audit procedures.

Question Text: Do you utilize any third party/open source/proprietary frameworks to manage encryption keys
Comment: IBP utilizes AWS Key Management Service as the primary key management framework, supplemented by application-level key handling through established cryptographic libraries. All key management solutions are industry-standard with documented security validation and regular security updates as specified in our Data Protection and Privacy Policy.

Question Text: Do you encrypt tenant data at rest (on disk/storage) within your environment
Comment: All tenant data is encrypted at rest using AES-256 encryption through AWS managed services including RDS database encryption, S3 server-side encryption, and EBS volume encryption as documented in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. Customer-managed KMS keys are available for enhanced encryption control and key ownership.

Question Text: Do you leverage encryption to protect data and virtual machine images during transport across and between networks and hypervisor instances
Comment: All data transport uses TLS 1.3 encryption including inter-service communications, cross-region replication, and VM image transfers as specified in the Data Protection and Privacy Policy. AWS provides encrypted transport for all managed services with certificate validation and secure channel establishment for all data movement.

Question Text: Do you have documentation establishing and defining your encryption management policies, procedures, and guidelines
Comment: The Data Protection and Privacy Policy provides comprehensive encryption management documentation including algorithms, key management procedures, usage guidelines, and compliance requirements. Documentation covers encryption at rest, in transit, key lifecycle management, and access control procedures with regular reviews and updates.

Question Text: Do you have platform and data appropriate encryption that uses open/validated formats and standard algorithms

Question Text: Do you make standards-based information security metrics (CSA, CAMM, etc.) available to your tenants?\n\nIf yes, please specify which metrics
Comment: While we maintain security metrics internally and can complete assessments like this CAIQ, we do not currently provide formal standards-based security metrics to customers. We could develop CSA-aligned reporting capabilities for enterprise customer requirements.

Question Text: Do you provide customers with ongoing visibility and reporting of your SLA performance?
Comment: We do not currently provide formal SLA performance reporting to customers, though we maintain internal performance monitoring. Regular SLA reporting would be developed as part of enterprise customer service agreements.

Question Text: Do your data management policies and procedures address tenant and service level conflicts of interests?
Comment: Our Data Protection Policy and Access Control Policy establish clear data segregation and tenant isolation procedures preventing conflicts of interest through strict data separation and independent access controls for each customer.

Question Text: Do you review all service level agreements at least annually?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy mandates annual review of service agreements including performance assessment and terms validation. Customer service agreements would follow similar annual review processes.

Question Text: Do you assure reasonable information security across your information supply chain by performing an annual review?\n\nDo you have any contractual obligations with providers to ensure security requirements are met?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy requires annual security reviews for all critical vendors and establishes contractual security obligations including compliance with security standards and incident notification requirements for all vendors handling customer data.

Question Text: Does your annual review include all partners/third-party providers upon which your information supply chain depends?
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes comprehensive vendor management covering all third-party providers in our supply chain including critical vendors, standard vendors, and subprocessors with risk-based assessment procedures.

Question Text: Do you mandate annual information security reviews and audits of your third party providers to ensure that all agreed upon security requirements are met?\n\nPlease describe this process
Comment: Our Vendor Management Policy establishes annual security reviews for critical vendors including security questionnaires, SOC 2 report reviews, and compliance verification. We maintain vendor security assessments with documented findings and corrective action tracking.

Question Text: Do you have external third party services conduct vulnerability scans and periodic penetration tests on your applications and networks?\n\nWhat tools are used? Can you provide results?
Comment: While we utilize AWS native security scanning and have comprehensive internal vulnerability management procedures, we do not currently conduct external third-party penetration testing. We plan to implement external security assessments and can accommodate this requirement for enterprise customers.

Question Text: Do you have anti-malware programs that support or connect to your cloud service offerings installed on all of your IT infrastructure network and systems components?\n\nWhat tools are used?
Comment: Our security framework includes AWS GuardDuty for cloud-native threat detection and our Remote Work Security Policy requires anti-malware software on all devices. We utilize AWS security services and endpoint protection, though comprehensive anti-malware deployment across all infrastructure components is ongoing.

Question Text: Do you ensure that security threat detection systems using signatures, lists, or behavioral patterns are updated across all infrastructure components as prescribed by industry best practices?\n\nWhat tools are used?
Comment: Our threat detection utilizes AWS GuardDuty with automatic threat intelligence updates, CloudWatch for behavioral monitoring, and AWS Config for compliance monitoring. Security systems receive automatic updates, though comprehensive coverage across all infrastructure components is progressive.

Question Text: Do you conduct network-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes vulnerability management using AWS Inspector and network security assessments. We conduct regular vulnerability scanning of network infrastructure with documented response procedures, though scan frequency is optimized for our organizational scale.

Question Text: Do you conduct application-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes application security scanning integrated into our development processes using static analysis and dependency scanning. We conduct regular application vulnerability assessments with defined remediation requirements for identified issues.

Question Text: Do you conduct local operating system-layer vulnerability scans regularly as prescribed by industry best practices?
Comment: We utilize AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager for operating system vulnerability management and patching. We conduct regular OS vulnerability scanning with automated patching capabilities and vulnerability tracking with defined response timeframes.

Question Text: Will you make the results of vulnerability scans available to tenants at their request?
Comment: Our policies support transparency with customers regarding security assessments. We can provide vulnerability scan summaries and security assessment results to customers under appropriate confidentiality agreements, with customer-specific risk assessments available.

Question Text: Do you have a capability to patch vulnerabilities across all of your computing devices, applications, and systems?\n\nPlease specify your patching timeframes for Critical/High/Medium findings.
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy establishes patch management using AWS Systems Manager with defined timeframes: Critical (24 hours), High (72 hours), Medium (7 days). We maintain automated patching capabilities with testing and rollback procedures.

Question Text: Do you inform customers (tenant) of policies and procedures and identified weaknesses if customer (tenant) data is used as part the service and/or customer (tenant) has some shared responsibility over implementation of control?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy follows the AWS shared responsibility model and we provide customers with documentation of security policies and shared responsibilities. We communicate security findings that require customer awareness through appropriate channels.

Question Text: Is mobile code authorized before its installation and use, and the code configuration checked, to ensure that the authorized mobile code operates according to a clearly defined security policy?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy establishes code security requirements including review procedures and security validation. All code deployments require security review and compliance verification before production deployment through documented approval processes.

Question Text: Is all unauthorized mobile code prevented from executing?
Comment: Our Technology Security Policy includes application security controls and deployment restrictions. We utilize AWS security controls and access restrictions to prevent unauthorized code execution with monitoring for non-approved execution attempts.
